questions.text: In the imaging of the saphenofemoral junction, which sign represents the relationship between the femoral artery, femoral vein, and saphenous vein?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Mickey mouse sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Stemmer's sign: Stemmer's sign is a clinical sign used in the diagnosis of lymphedema ; it indicates the presence of non-pitting edema , where the skin cannot be easily lifted at the base of the second toe or finger.
  • • Option B. Stemmer's sign:
  • • diagnosis of lymphedema
  • • presence of non-pitting edema
  • • Option C. Tillaux sign: Tillaux sign is a clinical sign in orthopedics related to an avulsion fracture of the anterolateral tibial epiphysis in adolescents , not related to vascular structures.
  • • Option C. Tillaux sign:
  • • clinical sign in orthopedics
  • • avulsion fracture
  • • anterolateral tibial epiphysis
  • • adolescents
  • • Option D. String sign: The string sign is used to describe the appearance of a long , narrow constriction seen in conditions such as Crohn's disease or in imaging of arteries that are severely narrowed.
  • • Option D. String sign:
  • • appearance of a long
  • • narrow
  • • constriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The "Mickey Mouse sign " on ultrasound is a descriptive term for the normal arrangement of the femoral vessels at the saphenofemoral junction , aiding in the identification and assessment of vascular structures in this area.
  • ➤ "Mickey Mouse sign
  • ➤ ultrasound
  • ➤ descriptive term
  • ➤ normal arrangement
  • ➤ femoral vessels
  • ➤ saphenofemoral junction
  • ➤ identification
  • ➤ assessment
  • ➤ vascular structures
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No

Ans. C. Lentiform nucleus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structures labelled are:
  • • Option A . Caudate nucleus
  • • Option A
  • • Option B . Insular cortex
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Option D . Thalamus
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • The Lentiform nucleus itself is composed of the putamen and the globus pallidus and is a key component of the basal ganglia system involved in the regulation of voluntary movement .
  • • Lentiform nucleus
  • • composed of the putamen
  • • globus pallidus
  • • basal ganglia system
  • • regulation of voluntary movement
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Axial MRI at the level of basal ganglia
  • • Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 748
  • • Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 748

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image shown below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.  IVC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure indicated by the arrow in the CT image is the Inferior Vena Cava (IVC). It's typically located posterior to the liver and anterior to the vertebral column and aorta on axial images .
  • • CT image
  • • Inferior Vena Cava
  • • posterior to the liver
  • • anterior
  • • vertebral column
  • • aorta
  • • axial images
  • • Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition
  • • Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: Which artery has been shown in the following CT angiographic image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Superior mesenteric artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The artery shown in the image is the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which can be identified by its characteristic branching pattern from the aorta below the coeliac trunk and supplying the midgut . It typically has multiple branches that supply the small intestine and the right side of the colon . The SMA's distinct trunk and its branches into the small bowel mesentery help differentiate it from other abdominal vessels on imaging.
  • • superior mesenteric artery
  • • branching pattern from the aorta below the coeliac trunk
  • • supplying the midgut
  • • multiple branches
  • • small intestine
  • • right side of the colon
  • • SMA's
  • • trunk
  • • small bowel mesentery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Left atrium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The heart chamber indicated in the CT image provided is the left atrium . It is located posteriorly within the heart's four chambers and can be identified on a CT scan by its position relative to the other heart chambers , the pulmonary veins draining into it, and its anatomical relationship to the esophagus and descending aorta .
  • • heart chamber
  • • CT image
  • • left atrium
  • • located posteriorly
  • • heart's four chambers
  • • identified on a CT scan
  • • position
  • • heart chambers
  • • pulmonary veins draining
  • • esophagus and descending aorta
  • • Educational objective:

  • • Ref

questions.text: What is name of the structure marked by tip of arrow?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Descending Aorta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure indicated by the tip of the arrow in the CT image is the descending aorta . It is located in the posterior mediastinum to the left of the thoracic vertebral bodies and carries blood from the arch of the aorta down through the thorax to the abdomen .
  • • descending aorta
  • • posterior mediastinum
  • • left of the thoracic vertebral bodies
  • • carries blood
  • • arch of the aorta
  • • thorax to the abdomen

questions.text: Identify the given structure on MR angiography:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Basilar Artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • The structure indicated in the MR angiography image is the basilar artery . It is a key artery located at the base of the brain and formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries . It ascends along the pons' anterior surface and bifurcates into the posterior cerebral arteries.
  • • MR angiography
  • • basilar artery
  • • key artery
  • • base of the brain
  • • union of the two vertebral arteries
  • • ascends along the pons' anterior surface
  • • bifurcates into the posterior cerebral arteries.
